channel.title: Ubuntu 10.10 java error
channel.description:
hi... i recently upgraded my ubuntu to 10.10 and now i try to install netbeans again... but when i try to install it i get this error :(
[IMG]http://i621.photobucket.com/albums/tt292/kneistol/screenshot1.png[/img]
i have jdk installed from program center but dont from java.com because i don't know how to open an .bin file :(
anyone please help me :P

item.title: Ubuntu 10.10 java error
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“kneistol, post:4, topic:367788”]i got it work but now i have a problem with my java folder… i tried to install the bin file and i got it work but now i can’t delete this folder

http://i621.photobucket.com/albums/tt292/kneistol/screenshot1-1.png

any help on how to delete it?[/quote]

Change directories to your desktop and remove it with root privileges.

sudo rm -rf jdk1.6.0_22

As for installing from the repos,

Go to Applications > Ubuntu Software Center. When it loads up, Edit > Software Sources. Under the “Other Software” tab, check the boxes for Canonical Partners, and then hit the Close button. And when it asks you to Reload, go ahead and do that.

Afterwards open up a terminal, and it should be as simple as

sudo apt-get install sun-java6-jre sun-java6-jdk sun-java6-plugin

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu 10.10 java error
item.dc:creator: @kneistol kneistol
item.description:
@kneistol wrote:

i got it work but now i have a problem with my java folder… i tried to install the bin file and i got it work but now i can’t delete this folder

any help on how to delete it?

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu 10.10 java error
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Actually, this will tell you where java is installed, although it is almost always installed to this location (probably always):

$ ls -l /etc/alternatives/javac
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 33 2010-10-12 14:12 /etc/alternatives/javac -> /usr/lib/jvm/java-6-sun/bin/javac

So, in my case, and probably yours, ‘/usr/lib/jvm/java-6-sun’ is your path to java.

Also, to run a ‘.bin’ file, you just run it from the command line (chmod +x filename.bin; ./filename.bin), but you don’t want to install java that way, install it from the repos.

Read full topic

@Mopman wrote:

if java is on the path (which it should be if you isntalled from software center) which javac in the terminal will tell you the full location, which you can paste into that box

edit: nvm that might not work ubuntu does the cute spreading out shit game
try it anyway though
